Award.AwardTitle: Signal Processing for Digital Analog Interface

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract:<br/><br/>This research explores how techniques from coding and signal processing can be<br/>used to build better analog to digital and digital to analog converters, create better half toning algorithms<br/>for digital printing,and improve medical imaging. All of these as well as many other applications use a technique called<br/>Sigma Delta modulation. Sigma Delta modulation is a technique which allows high precision<br/>signal to be generated from binary quantized data. This research provides a new interpretation of Sigma Delta<br/>modulation by viewing it as a greedy solution to an optimization problem instead<br/>of a linear system with feedback.<br/><br/>This new view not only explains how existing Sigma Delta modulators work but also<br/>suggests a whole new continuum of modulator structures which can<br/>trade complexity against performance. The research has two main<br/>thrusts, one practical and experimental and the other theoretical.<br/>The practical thrust will improve upon the existing empirical<br/>approaches to conventional Sigma Delta modulator design and then<br/>adapt them to new modulator structures suggested by the optimization<br/>approach. This research should yield immediate benefits for the<br/>numerous areas where Sigma Delta modulators are used now as well<br/>as new applications that will become viable because of this<br/>research. The theoretical thrust will develop a rigorous<br/>understanding of the quantization process. <br/><br/><br/><br/>
